kse.utilclass.lists

Class SortedArrayList<E>

  • java.lang.Object
    • java.util.AbstractCollection<E>
      • java.util.AbstractList<E>
        • java.util.ArrayList<E>
          • kse.utilclass.lists.SortedArrayList<E>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - elements must be comparable either by their nature (implementing the Comparable interface) or through a user-supplied Comparator<? super E>.
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Iterable<E>, java.util.Collection<E>, java.util.List<E>, java.util.RandomAccess

    public class SortedArrayList<E>
extends java.util.ArrayList<E>
    A list structure derived from ArrayList<E> which orders its elements in a given or natural sorting. The natural sorting is in place if no comparator is set by the user.

    The list allows for null elements if and only if a comparator is explicitly given and this comparator allows for null arguments to be compared. If this condition is not met, a NullPointerException is thrown by any attempt to add the null element.

    If instances have to be serialised, any comparator supplied needs to implement the java.io.Serializable interface.

    See Also:
    Serialized Form

    • Method Detail

      • add

        public boolean add(E e)
        Adds the specified element to this list. If the element is not comparable with the other elements of this list, an exception is thrown.

        NOTE: null is a legal value if and only if a comparator has been set up allowing for such comparison.

        Specified by:
        add in interface java.util.Collection<E>
        Specified by:
        add in interface java.util.List<E>
        Overrides:
        add in class java.util.ArrayList<E>
        Parameters:
        e - E element to add
        Returns:
        boolean true
        Throws:
        java.lang.ClassCastException - if the specified object cannot be compared
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the specified element is null and this list uses natural ordering, or its comparator does not permit null elements

      • add

        public void add(int index,
                E e)
        This method has been overridden to be equivalent with 'add(e)', i.e. the index parameter is ignored as pointed insertion is not allowed in a sorted list.
        Specified by:
        add in interface java.util.List<E>
        Overrides:
        add in class java.util.ArrayList<E>
        Parameters:

        e - E element to add
        Throws:
        java.lang.ClassCastException - if the specified object cannot be compared
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the specified element is null and this list uses natural ordering, or its comparator does not permit null elements

      • setComparator

        public void setComparator(java.util.Comparator<? super E> c)
        Sets the Comparator defining the order on the elements of this set. A value of null sets usage of the natural sorting of the elements. If the set contains elements, it is implicitly resorted by a call of this method.

        NOTE: Natural sorting excludes the use of null elements.

        NOTE: If this instance of SortedArrayList shall be serialised, the given comparator has to implement the java.io.Serializable interface.

        Parameters:
        c - Comparator<? super E>, null for "natural ordering"

      • comparator

        public java.util.Comparator<? super E> comparator()
        Returns the comparator used to order the elements in this list, or null if this list uses the natural ordering of its elements.
        Returns:
        Comparator<? super E> or null

      • resort

        protected void resort()
        Resorts the content of this list according to the active sorting.

      • set

        public E set(int index,
             E element)
        Replaces the element at the specified position in this list with the specified element. This operation only works for arguments which designate the same sorting-value as of the existing element at the given position.
        Specified by:
        set in interface java.util.List<E>
        Overrides:
        set in class java.util.ArrayList<E>
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if element has a different identity than the list entry at index
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - if the index is out of range (index < 0 | index >= size())
        java.lang.NullPointerException - if the specified element is null and this list uses natural ordering, or its comparator does not permit null elements

      • sort

        public void sort(java.util.Comparator<? super E> c)
        The sort method from interface List sets the given comparator as ruling in this sorted-list and resorts the content. This is equivalent with setComparator(c) in this implementation.
        Specified by:
        sort in interface java.util.List<E>
        Overrides:
        sort in class java.util.ArrayList<E>
